thread.title: PHOTO REPORT: The 191st anniversary of the Annexation of Nicoya is a hot, lively affair
thread.title_full: PHOTO REPORT: The 191st anniversary of the Annexation of Nicoya is a hot, lively affair -The Tico Times

author: Andrés Madrigal
title: PHOTO REPORT: The 191st anniversary of the Annexation of Nicoya is a hot, lively affair
text:
See also: Water protests greet Costa Rica’s Solís in Nicoya during annual festival
On Saturday, the people of Costa Rica’s northwestern province of Guanacaste dusted off their cowboy boots and headed out for a traditional Tico celebration at the annual Annexation of the Partido de Nicoya Festival. Held every July 25, this year’s festival commemorated the 191st anniversary of the day when the Partido de Nicoya, today known as Guanacaste, became a part of Costa Rica in 1824. This year’s event, held under a scorching sun that sent temperatures skyrocketing, was lively and hot, with plenty of protests and an equal measure of fun.
Demonstrators from several towns in the province of Guanacaste turned out for the annual holiday in Nicoya on Saturday, July 25, 2015.
Andrés Madrigal/The Tico Times
A young Nicoyano proudly wears the Costa Rican and Guanacaste flags.
Andrés Madrigal/The Tico Times
Marimbas played throughout most of the day at Nicoya´s Central Square on Saturday, July 25, 2015.
Andrés Madrigal/The Tico Times
When Guanacaste grows, Costa Rica is ennobled.
Andrés Madrigal/The Tico Times
 Solís took the stage on Saturday to deliver a speech under the blistering Guanacaste sun.
Andrés Madrigal/The Tico Times
Not everyone complained about Solís.
Andrés Madrigal/The Tico Times
Guanacaste is hot and rowdy and tons of fun.
Andrés Madrigal/The Tico Times
Ready for the tope, a traditional and lively horse parade celebrating Guanacaste’s cowboy and cowgirl culture.
Andrés Madrigal/The Tico Times
Generations of horse riders participate in Saturday’s large tope.
Andrés Madrigal/The Tico Times
Fist bumps on horseback.
Andrés Madrigal/The Tico Times
Matching hats and pretty smiles.
Andrés Madrigal/The Tico Times
Nice horse.
Andrés Madrigal/The Tico Times
After only traveling five blocks, several riders make a quick stop to quench their thirst, another Guanacaste tradition.
Andrés Madrigal/The Tico Times
